Social Welfare Maximization for Federated Learning with Network Effects

Xiang Li, Yuan Luo, Bing Luo, Jianwei Huang††footnotetext: Xiang Li is with Shenzhen Institute of Artificial Intelligence and Robotics for Society (AIRS), and the School of Science and Engineering (SSE), The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen (E-mail: xiangli2@link.cuhk.edu.cn). Yuan Luo is with SSE, AIRS, and Shenzhen Key Laboratory of Crowd Intelligence Empowered Low-Carbon Energy Network, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen (E-mail: luoyuan@cuhk.edu.cn). Bing Luo is with Data Science Research Center, Duke Kunshan University, Jiangsu (E-mail: bl291@duke.edu). Jianwei Huang is with SSE, AIRS, Shenzhen Key Laboratory of Crowd Intelligence Empowered Low-Carbon Energy Network, and CSIJRI Joint Research Centre on Smart Energy Storage, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen, Guangdong, 518172, P.R. China (Corresponding Author, E-mail: jianweihuang@cuhk.edu.cn).
(2024)
Abstract.

A proper mechanism design can help federated learning (FL) to achieve good social welfare by coordinating self-interested clients through the learning process. However, existing mechanisms neglect the network effects of client participation, leading to suboptimal incentives and social welfare. This paper addresses this gap by exploring network effects in FL incentive mechanism design. We establish a theoretical model to analyze FL model performance and quantify the impact of network effects on heterogeneous client participation. Our analysis reveals the non-monotonic nature of FL network effects. To leverage such effects, we propose a model trading and sharing (MTS) framework that allows clients to obtain FL models through participation or purchase. To tackle heterogeneous clients’ strategic behaviors, we further design a socially efficient model trading and sharing (SEMTS) mechanism. Our mechanism achieves social welfare maximization solely through customer payments, without additional incentive costs. Experimental results on an FL hardware prototype demonstrate up to 148.86%percent148.86148.86\% improvement in social welfare compared to existing mechanisms.

Federated Learning, Mechanism Design, Network Effects

1. Introduction

Federated learning (FL) (Zhan et al., 2022; Tu et al., 2022; Khan et al., 2020) is an emerging machine learning (ML) paradigm that exploits massive data (Nguyen et al., 2021) and resources (Guo et al., 2021) across devices. As a collaborative approach, FL enables clients to enjoy the utility of employing well-trained models through participation, promising to deliver significant social welfare (i.e., the total payoffs for all parties involved (Zeng et al., 2021)). However, given the costs associated with model training, e.g., data labeling and computational costs (Zhao et al., 2023), self-interested clients may hesitate to participate and contribute their resources. Specifically, under existing FL frameworks (e.g., (McMahan et al., 2017; Tan et al., 2022; Abdulrahman et al., 2021)), although clients can obtain and utilize the trained model through participation, the utility derived via employing the model could be insufficient to offset their costs, thereby discouraging their participation. With limited client participation, FL struggles to realize the full benefits of collaboration and maximize social welfare. Therefore, from the perspective of system efficiency (Chinchuluun et al., 2008), designing a socially efficient (i.e., social welfare maximizing) mechanism is essential for FL to succeed.

Recent studies have made impressive progress in optimizing social welfare through mechanism design for FL, e.g., (Thi Le et al., 2021; Lin et al., 2022; Lee et al., 2020; Jiao et al., 2021; Saputra et al., 2023; Zhan et al., 2020; Luo et al., 2023; Zhan et al., 2022). However, they often neglect the network effects (Easley and Kleinberg, 2012) arising from client participation. Specifically, network effects111In economics, network effect is a phenomenon where a product’s utility varies with its client number, which often exhibits monotonicity, either positive (i.e., utility increases with clients, as in social networking services) or negative (e.g., network congestion). refer to the interdependence between client participation, trained FL model performance, and corresponding utility, which vary with the network size (participant number). These effects influence the correlation between clients’ participation decisions. For example, as more clients contribute to FL, training models with higher utility become more feasible, thus attracting even more participants in a positive cycle. Conversely, due to data heterogeneity (Luo et al., 2021), more clients may also yield models with lower utility, discouraging client participation, as depicted in Figure 1. Ignoring such network effects could lead to improper incentive mechanism design at different stages, either underpaying or overpaying clients, failing to adapt to the dynamics of clients’ participation decisions. Motivated by this, we investigate the following key question in this paper:

Key Question 0.

How to design a socially efficient mechanism for federated learning with network effects?

To address the key question above, we propose a Model Trading and Sharing (MTS) framework

, inspired by the emerging ML model markets (e.g., (Str, [n. d.]; Gra, [n. d.])), to exploit network effects in FL and enhance social welfare. The MTS framework, as illustrated in Figure 2, allows clients to obtain and utilize FL models in two ways: by participating in model training as a participant, or by purchasing trained models as a model customer. With this additional purchasing option, FL models are more accessible to clients (e.g., for those with high participation costs or limited data size), and payments from model customers can trigger network effects that promote client participation and increase social welfare.

However, clients’ strategic decisions prioritize optimizing their individual payoff and potentially deviate from socially optimal decisions. As a result, we need to further design a socially efficient mechanism for the MTS framework, while the unique characteristics of FL with network effects make it highly challenging. Specifically, due to the client data statistical heterogeneity (i.e., data size and distribution heterogeneity (Yan and Ligeti, 2022)) and the distributed nature of FL, quantifying the trained model performance requires complex theoretical models (Karimireddy et al., 2020). This inherent complexity makes it difficult to evaluate network effects by determining the expected model utility and payoff that clients derive from participation. Furthermore, the privacy-preserving feature of FL restricts clients from accessing each other’s private information, which leads to an incomplete information game, and the extra purchasing option expands clients’ decision space even further.

Against this background, we first delve into the linear FL models, which are insightful for nonlinear models (Smith et al., 2017; Liang et al., 2020; Hastie et al., 2022; Mei and Montanari, 2022; Krogh and Hertz, 1992). Through the linear model setting and the quantification of network effects on FL model performance, we explore the Nash equilibrium (Mas-Colell et al., 1995) among multiple clients with incomplete information. Building upon these, we design a Socially Efficient Model Trading and Sharing (SEMTS) mechanism that exploits the network effects of client participation. The SEMTS mechanism incentivizes heterogeneous clients to maximize social welfare using only payments from model customers, without incurring extra incentive costs.

This paper advances the state of the art in the following ways:

  • •

    The MTS Framework for FL: To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study on social welfare optimization in FL with network effects. We propose the Model Trading and Sharing (MTS) framework for FL to make models more accessible to clients and enhance social welfare. The MTS framework allows clients to obtain and utilize the trained global FL model either by participating in training or purchasing directly.

  • •

    Network Effects Analysis: Our analysis reveals insights into network effects on heterogeneous client participation and model performance. Counter-intuitively, we show that FL network effects are not monotonic but potentially transit between positive and negative. In scenarios with low data distribution heterogeneity (i.e., non-i.i.d. level of client data), as more clients participate, FL model performance and utility decrease first and then increase. In contrast, with high data distribution heterogeneity, network effects of client participation will exhibit a reverse trend, initially positive but eventually turning negative.

  • •

    Socially Efficient Mechanism Design: Based on the quantification of FL network effects, we derive clients’ strategic decisions under incomplete information and incorporate them into the mechanism design for the MTS framework. Specifically, we design a Socially Efficient Model Trading and Sharing (SEMTS) mechanism. By exploiting the network effects of client participation, our designed mechanism maximizes social welfare, relying on payments received from model customers rather than incurring extra incentive costs.

  • •

    Experimental Evaluation with Hardware Prototype: We empirically evaluate our proposed mechanism and MTS framework on a hardware prototype of FL. The extensive experiments validate our analysis of network effects in FL and demonstrate that our mechanism can improve social welfare by up to 148.86%percent148.86148.86\%, compared to the theoretical upper bound of existing FL mechanisms that do not consider network effects.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 reviews related works of mechanism design and network effects in FL. Section 3 introduces the system model and problem formulation. Section 4 presents our proposed MTS framework, which includes the mechanism design through the analysis of network effects. Section 5 provides the experimental evaluation on an FL hardware prototype. We conclude this paper in Section 6. Due to the page limit, we leave detailed proof of our results and extra empirical experiments in the online appendix (Li et al., [n. d.]).

2. Related Works

The mechanism design for social welfare optimization of FL (e.g., (Thi Le et al., 2021; Lin et al., 2022; Lee et al., 2020; Jiao et al., 2021; Saputra et al., 2023; Zhan et al., 2020; Luo et al., 2023; Liao et al., 5555; Luo et al., 2021)) has made considerable advancements, as summarized in recent surveys (Zhan et al., 2022; Tu et al., 2022; Khan et al., 2020). Specifically, Lee et al. in (Lee et al., 2020) formulated the interaction of participants in FL as a Stackelberg game to maximize social welfare. Jiao et al. in (Jiao et al., 2021) proposed an auction-based market model for incentivizing clients to participate in FL, which can efficiently maximize the social welfare. Saputra et al. in (Saputra et al., 2023) developed a contract-based policy to increase the social welfare of vanilla FL methods. Zhan et al. in (Zhan et al., 2020) evaluated ambiguous contributions in FL through a learning-based algorithm, which improves the overall payoff for participants.

However, these works typically overlook the network effects in FL, which in practice could cause existing mechanisms to either underpay or overpay clients for incentivizing their participation. In contrast, this paper theoretically analyzes the network effects of client participation, which is relatively under-explored and more complex given the unique attributes of FL. By leveraging network effects, our designed mechanism can incentivize clients’ participation to maximize the social welfare without requiring extra incentives.

The only paper that studies network effects in FL is (Hu et al., 2023) by Hu et al., which investigated the client’s evolving expectation of FL performance by modeling client behavior as a network effects game. However, this literature focused on the participation equilibrium analysis in FL, without fully considering client heterogeneity and social welfare. Specifically, they assumed that all clients share an expectation about the FL coalition and that client participation will always improve the trained model. In reality, clients often lack information about others’ decisions, and FL model performance varies with the data statistical heterogeneity. This incomplete information and the impact of heterogeneity could lead their mechanism to fail to incentivize diverse clients for the desired equilibrium. In contrast, this paper designs a mechanism to incentivize the participation of heterogeneous clients with incomplete information, aiming to maximize the social welfare in FL.

3. System Model and Problem Formulation

In this section, we begin by introducing the fundamentals of FL and modeling heterogeneous clients. Then, we specify our proposed MTS framework and formulate the mechanism design problem for social welfare optimization within it.

3.1. Preliminaries of Federated Learning

FL is a distributed ML paradigm that leverages multiple clients’ resources to collaboratively train a shared model. To illustrate how FL works, we first provide an overview of the FL training process.

We consider a set of clients 𝒩={1,2,⋯,N}𝒩12⋯𝑁\mathcal{N}=\{1,2,\cdots,N\} interested in FL model training, which involves N𝑁N clients with heterogeneous characteristics. By participating in the training process, clients can obtain and utilize the trained global FL model. However, the FL model training process also incurs related costs for participants, e.g., due to resource consumption and data processing. Consequently, the self-interested N𝑁N clients may not fully participate in FL.

Let 𝒦⊆𝒩𝒦𝒩\mathcal{K}\subseteq\mathcal{N} denote the set of participants involved in the FL training process. Each participant k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} will utilize the private data set 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} of size Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} to train a model. The local training objective of participant k𝑘k is to find the proper model parameters 𝒘𝒘\boldsymbol{w} that minimize the average loss Fk​(𝒘)subscript𝐹𝑘𝒘F_{k}(\boldsymbol{w}) across all data samples d∈𝒟k𝑑subscript𝒟𝑘d\in\mathcal{D}_{k}:

(1) Fk​(𝒘)=1Dk​∑d∈𝒟kf​(𝒘;d),subscript𝐹𝑘𝒘1subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑑subscript𝒟𝑘𝑓𝒘𝑑F_{k}(\boldsymbol{w})=\frac{1}{D_{k}}\sum\nolimits_{d\in\mathcal{D}_{k}}f(\boldsymbol{w};d),

where f​(⋅)𝑓⋅f(\cdot) represents the per-sample loss function.

With locally trained models, FL aims to tackle the global loss optimization problem based on all participants’ data, i.e., learn the optimal model parameters 𝒘∗superscript𝒘\boldsymbol{w}^{*} to minimize the weighted average of all participants’ local loss functions:

(2) 𝒘∗=arg⁡min𝒘⁡F​(𝒘)=arg⁡min𝒘​∑k∈𝒦Dk∑k∈𝒦Dk​Fk​(𝒘).superscript𝒘subscript𝒘𝐹𝒘subscript𝒘subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝐹𝑘𝒘\boldsymbol{w}^{*}=\arg\min_{\boldsymbol{w}}F(\boldsymbol{w})=\arg\min_{\boldsymbol{w}}\sum\nolimits_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\frac{D_{k}}{\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}D_{k}}F_{k}(\boldsymbol{w}).

After introducing the preliminaries of FL, we then present heterogeneous clients interested in implementing FL.

3.2. Heterogeneous Clients Modeling

This subsection describes heterogeneous characteristics of clients, along with their participation cost and model utility.

3.2.1. Heterogeneous Clients

We study a set 𝒩={1,2,⋯,N}𝒩12⋯𝑁\mathcal{N}=\{1,2,\cdots,N\} of N𝑁N clients with data statistical heterogeneity in FL, including both data distribution heterogeneity (i.e., non-i.i.d nature of client data) and data size heterogeneity.

  • •

    To capture data distribution heterogeneity, as explored in (Hastie et al., 2022; Smith et al., 2017; Liang et al., 2020), we consider the local feature represented by each client’s data set independently follow a Gaussian distribution with diagonal covariances of σ2∈ℝdsuperscript𝜎2superscriptℝ𝑑\sigma^{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, where d𝑑d is the feature dimension. With larger σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}, the local features differ more across clients’ respective data, indicating a higher client variance. Similarly, for the naturally occurring data variance (Montgomery et al., 2021), we incorporate it as noise δ∼𝒩​(0,γ2)similar-to𝛿𝒩0superscript𝛾2\delta\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\gamma^{2}) on the training targets, following a Gaussian distribution with variance γ2superscript𝛾2\gamma^{2}.

  • •

    Regarding data size heterogeneity of clients, we distinguish N𝑁N clients into a set ℐ={1,2,⋯,I}ℐ12⋯𝐼\mathcal{I}=\{1,2,\cdots,I\} of I𝐼I types by their different data sizes. Specifically, we refer to a client with data size Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} as a type i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I} client. Let 𝒩isubscript𝒩𝑖\mathcal{N}_{i} denote the set of Nisubscript𝑁𝑖N_{i} type-i𝑖i clients, where ∪i∈ℐ𝒩i=𝒩subscript𝑖ℐsubscript𝒩𝑖𝒩\cup_{i\in\mathcal{I}}\mathcal{N}_{i}=\mathcal{N} and ∑i∈ℐNi=Nsubscript𝑖ℐsubscript𝑁𝑖𝑁\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}N_{i}=N. Without loss of generality, we assume a larger index indicates a larger data size, i.e., Di≤Djsubscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝐷𝑗D_{i}\leq D_{j}, if i≤j𝑖𝑗i\leq j, for any i,j∈ℐ𝑖𝑗ℐi,j\in\mathcal{I}.

3.2.2. Participation Cost

For heterogeneous clients, participating in the FL model training process with their private data will incur a cost of resource consumption (e.g., computation and communication resources) and data processing (e.g., data labeling). This participation cost often positively222This positive correlation only aims to align with real-world situations, which will not affect our theoretical analysis and mechanism design later. correlates with the client’s data size, as illustrated in (Zhao et al., 2023; Karimireddy et al., 2022). Hence, we denote Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i} as the participation cost of type-i𝑖i clients, with Ci≤Cjsubscript𝐶𝑖subscript𝐶𝑗C_{i}\leq C_{j}, if i≤j𝑖𝑗i\leq j, for any i,j∈ℐ𝑖𝑗ℐi,j\in\mathcal{I}.

3.2.3. FL Model Utility

According to research on ML model markets (Chen et al., 2019b; Liu et al., 2021; Agarwal et al., 2019), the client’s utility of employing the FL model relies heavily on how well it performs on future (unseen) data, i.e., the model’s generalization ability, quantified by the generalization error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. We thus define U​(ϵ)≥0𝑈italic-ϵ0U(\epsilon)\geq 0 as the client’s utility function of the FL model, which is non-increasing in ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, implying that a lower generalization error corresponds to a higher model utility for clients. Additionally, from the practical correlation333Due to page limit, we focus on such typical utility functions. The analysis is the same for other utility functions, detailed in our appendix (Li et al., [n. d.]). between FL model performance and utility, e.g., (Fernandez et al., 2020; Chen et al., 2019a; Cong et al., 2022), as the model performance improves, generalization error reduction tends to be increasingly valuable to clients. This trend continues until the generalization error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon reaches a certain threshold444As model improves, reducing ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is increasingly challenging and resource-intensive (Hestness et al., 2017), making error reductions more valuable (higher marginal utility) for clients. Nevertheless, once the model is sufficient for its intended application, further improvements will yield diminishingly perceptible benefits., which we associate with feature variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}, i.e., (ϵ−σ2)​U′′​(ϵ)+2​U′​(ϵ)≥0italic-ϵsuperscript𝜎2superscript𝑈′′italic-ϵ2superscript𝑈′italic-ϵ0(\epsilon-\sigma^{2})U^{\prime\prime}(\epsilon)+2U^{\prime}(\epsilon)\geq 0, for all ϵ≠σ2italic-ϵsuperscript𝜎2\epsilon\neq\sigma^{2}.

Furthermore, as common in the literature (Hastie et al., 2022; Liang et al., 2020; Mei and Montanari, 2022), we adopt a student-teacher setup for FL to theoretically quantify the generalization error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon of the trained global model. Specifically, given the feature dimension d𝑑d, data variance γ2superscript𝛾2\gamma^{2}, and client variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} discussed in Section 3.2.1, we extend the analytical results in (Liang et al., 2020) (which studied homogeneous FL scenarios, assuming uniform participant data sizes) to account for heterogeneous participants and derive the generalization error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon as follows:

(3) ϵ=d​γ2K2​∑i∈ℐKiDi+K−1K​σ2,italic-ϵ𝑑superscript𝛾2superscript𝐾2subscript𝑖ℐsubscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖𝐾1𝐾superscript𝜎2\epsilon=\frac{d\gamma^{2}}{K^{2}}\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}}\frac{K_{i}}{D_{i}}+\frac{K-1}{K}\sigma^{2},

where Kisubscript𝐾𝑖K_{i} is the number of type-i𝑖i participants, for any i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I}. We give the derivation of (3) in the online appendix (Li et al., [n. d.]).

From (3), the generalization error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon comprises two distinct components: d​γ2K2​∑i∈ℐKiDi𝑑superscript𝛾2superscript𝐾2subscript𝑖ℐsubscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖\frac{d\gamma^{2}}{K^{2}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}\frac{K_{i}}{D_{i}} and K−1K​σ2𝐾1𝐾superscript𝜎2\frac{K-1}{K}\sigma^{2}, caused by data variance and client variance, respectively:

  • •

    The generalization error arising from data variance γ2superscript𝛾2\gamma^{2} exhibits an inverse relationship with both the number K𝐾K of participants and the harmonic mean K/(∑i∈ℐKi/Di)𝐾subscript𝑖ℐsubscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖{K}/({\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}K_{i}/D_{i}}) of their individual data sizes.

  • •

    In contrast, the impact of client variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} on the generalization error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon increases with the number of participants. That is, although involving more participants with more local data reduces the generalization error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon attributed to data variance γ2superscript𝛾2\gamma^{2}, it concurrently amplifies the error resulting from client variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}.

In conclusion, according to ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon in (3), the trained FL model performance depends on participants’ number and data statistical heterogeneity, implying an interdependence between utility and clients’ participation decisions, i.e., network effects. We also evaluate our theoretical results with nonlinear FL models through extensive experiments on an FL hardware prototype, elaborated in Section 5.

3.3. The MTS Frameworks of Federated Learning

While clients can enjoy FL model utility by participating in training, the associated participation costs may discourage some of them. To enhance model accessibility and exploit the network effects, we propose a Model Trading and Sharing (MTS) framework, which introduces an extra purchasing option for clients to obtain the trained model. In this subsection, we elaborate on the MTS framework, focusing on the decision space and the payoff of clients within it.

3.3.1. Client Decision

Under the MTS framework, heterogeneous clients have three available strategies: abstain from obtaining the FL model, participate555To deliver clear insights, we focus on full participation behaviors of clients rather than partial ones (i.e., randomly joining some rounds of FL training), where the latter will yield similar analytical results, as studied in (Wang and Ji, 2024; Yang et al., 2021). in the training process to obtain the FL model, or directly purchase the well-trained FL model. We denote the strategies of client n∈𝒩i𝑛subscript𝒩𝑖n\in\mathcal{N}_{i} with any type i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I} as sn∈{A,J,B}subscript𝑠𝑛𝐴𝐽𝐵s_{n}\in\{A,J,B\}, i.e.,

(4a) sn=subscript𝑠𝑛absent\displaystyle s_{n}= A,𝐴\displaystyle A, abstain from obtaining the FL model,
(4b) sn=subscript𝑠𝑛absent\displaystyle s_{n}= J,𝐽\displaystyle J, join FL to obtain the model,
(4c) sn=subscript𝑠𝑛absent\displaystyle s_{n}= B,𝐵\displaystyle B, buy the FL model.

Given clients’ decisions, we can calculate the total number of participants and FL model customers for any type i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I}, defined as Ki=∑n∈𝒩i𝟙sn∗=Jsubscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑖subscript1subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑛𝐽K_{i}=\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{i}}\mathds{1}_{s^{*}_{n}=J} and Bi=∑n∈𝒩i𝟙sn∗=Bsubscript𝐵𝑖subscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑖subscript1subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑛𝐵B_{i}=\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{i}}\mathds{1}_{s^{*}_{n}=B}, respectively. The indicator function 𝟙sn∗=Jsubscript1subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑛𝐽\mathds{1}_{s^{*}_{n}=J} means that client n𝑛n decides to participate in FL model training, while 𝟙sn∗=Bsubscript1subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑛𝐵\mathds{1}_{s^{*}_{n}=B} indicates that client n𝑛n decides to purchase the trained FL model. Since the number of type-i𝑖i clients is Nisubscript𝑁𝑖N_{i}, we can also determine the number of clients with strategy A𝐴A, which is Ni−Ki−Bisubscript𝑁𝑖subscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝐵𝑖N_{i}-K_{i}-B_{i}.

3.3.2. FL Model Price and Participation Reward

As illustrated in Figure 2, the MTS framework includes a platform that coordinates the FL model training and trading process. This platform enables heterogeneous clients to obtain the model by paying or, alternatively, by participating in training with a participation reward. We use p𝑝p to represent the price of the trained global FL model and denote risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} as the participation reward for type-i𝑖i clients. In order to focus on the socially efficient mechanism design for FL with network effects, we assume such a platform is non-profit666For the platform operating on a cost-recovery basis, the analysis is the same but incorporates the platform’s associated costs into social welfare. and aims to maximize the social welfare. That is, the platform only leverages all payments received from model customers to incentivize client participation and model improvements in FL, i.e.,

(5) ∑i∈ℐBi​p=∑i∈ℐKi​ri.subscript𝑖ℐsubscript𝐵𝑖𝑝subscript𝑖ℐsubscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}}B_{i}p=\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}}K_{i}r_{i}.

Note that the participation reward risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i}, for any i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I}, could be negative, which serves to penalize the participation of clients with poor contributions to the FL model performance and compensate other high-contributing participants.

3.3.3. Client Payoff

The payoff πnsubscript𝜋𝑛\pi_{n} of a type-i𝑖i client n∈𝒩i𝑛subscript𝒩𝑖n\in\mathcal{N}_{i}, for any i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I}, within the MTS framework is a function of all clients’ decisions, which also involves the model utility U​(ϵ)𝑈italic-ϵU(\epsilon), participation cost Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i}, participation reward risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i}, and model price p𝑝p. To simplify the notation, we denote the vector of all clients’ strategies (i.e., snsubscript𝑠𝑛s_{n} for all n∈𝒩𝑛𝒩n\in\mathcal{N}) as 𝒔𝒔\boldsymbol{s}, and summarize the payoff function of client n𝑛n with type i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I} as follows:

(6a) πn​(𝒔)=subscript𝜋𝑛𝒔absent\displaystyle\pi_{n}(\boldsymbol{s})= 0,0\displaystyle 0, if sn=Asubscript𝑠𝑛𝐴s_{n}=A,
(6b) πn​(𝒔)=subscript𝜋𝑛𝒔absent\displaystyle\pi_{n}(\boldsymbol{s})= U​(ϵ)−Ci+ri,𝑈italic-ϵsubscript𝐶𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖\displaystyle U(\epsilon)-C_{i}+r_{i}, if sn=Jsubscript𝑠𝑛𝐽s_{n}=J,
(6c) πn​(𝒔)=subscript𝜋𝑛𝒔absent\displaystyle\pi_{n}(\boldsymbol{s})= U​(ϵ)−p,𝑈italic-ϵ𝑝\displaystyle U(\epsilon)-p, if sn=Bsubscript𝑠𝑛𝐵s_{n}=B.

From (6a), if client n𝑛n abstains from acquiring the trained global FL model, the payoff πnsubscript𝜋𝑛\pi_{n} is zero. By participating in the FL model training process, the type-i𝑖i client n∈𝒩i𝑛subscript𝒩𝑖n\in\mathcal{N}_{i} will obtain the model utility U​(ϵ)𝑈italic-ϵU(\epsilon) and participation reward risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} while incurring the participation cost Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i}, as stated in (6b). When the client n𝑛n decides to purchase the trained FL model directly, the payoff πnsubscript𝜋𝑛\pi_{n} is the difference between model utility U​(ϵ)𝑈italic-ϵU(\epsilon) and model price p𝑝p, as expressed in (6c).

With the proposed MTS framework, we aim to optimize the social welfare in FL. Given the platform’s non-profit nature, as detailed in Section 3.3.2, the payoff of the platform will always be zero. That is, the objective of social welfare maximization is consistent with the maximization of clients’ total payoff. To this end, we next formulate the mechanism design problem for social welfare optimization.

3.4. Socially Efficient Mechanism Design Problem

To maximize the FL social welfare, the mechanism design problem under the MTS framework entails optimizing both FL model price p𝑝p and participation reward risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i}, for any i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I}, as elaborated below.

For a set of clients 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} interested in the FL model under the MTS framework, the payoff of the platform is zero, and thus the social welfare WMTSsubscript𝑊MTSW_{\textrm{MTS}} is the sum of each client’s payoff πnsubscript𝜋𝑛\pi_{n} in (6c), related to all clients’ strategies. Given the number of participants Kisubscript𝐾𝑖K_{i} and model customers Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i} of each client type i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I}, we can express the social welfare WMTSsubscript𝑊MTSW_{\textrm{MTS}} as follows:

(7) WMTS=∑i∈ℐ[Ki​(U​(ϵ)−Ci+ri)+Bi​(U​(ϵ)−p)].subscript𝑊MTSsubscript𝑖ℐdelimited-[]subscript𝐾𝑖𝑈italic-ϵsubscript𝐶𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖subscript𝐵𝑖𝑈italic-ϵ𝑝W_{\textrm{MTS}}=\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}}[K_{i}(U(\epsilon)-C_{i}+r_{i})+B_{i}(U(\epsilon)-p)].

According to WMTSsubscript𝑊MTSW_{\textrm{MTS}} in (7) and considering clients’ self-interested decision-making, i.e., making decisions that maximize their individual payoff, we formulate the mechanism design problem of social welfare optimization as Problem 1.

In the following section, we will design a socially efficient mechanism under the MTS framework to solve Problem 1. The mechanism takes into account both the FL model performance and the number of benefiting clients, leveraging the network effects of client participation to maximize the social welfare.

4. Mechanism Design with Network Effects

We first theoretically analyze the FL network effects. Then, building upon this analysis, we study the social efficiency of the MTS framework and propose the mechanism that maximizes social welfare.

4.1. Network Effects of Client Participation

FL enables clients to collaboratively train and share a model with the aim of generating accurate outputs for a particular task. Based on the generalization error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon derived in (3), we begin by exploring the impact of client collaboration in FL, as summarized in Corollary 4.1, in order to understand the network effects of client participation.

Corollary 0.

Consider two disjoint non-empty participant coalitions 𝒦asubscript𝒦𝑎\mathcal{K}_{a} and 𝒦bsubscript𝒦𝑏\mathcal{K}_{b}, where Hasubscript𝐻𝑎H_{a} and Hbsubscript𝐻𝑏H_{b} are the harmonic means of participants’ data sizes in 𝒦asubscript𝒦𝑎\mathcal{K}_{a} and 𝒦bsubscript𝒦𝑏\mathcal{K}_{b}, with Ha≤Hbsubscript𝐻𝑎subscript𝐻𝑏H_{a}\leq H_{b}. The generalization error ϵasubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑎\epsilon_{a} and ϵbsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\epsilon_{b} of the model trained by 𝒦asubscript𝒦𝑎\mathcal{K}_{a} and 𝒦bsubscript𝒦𝑏\mathcal{K}_{b} satisfies ϵa+b<max⁡{ϵa,ϵb}subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑎𝑏subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑎subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑏\epsilon_{a+b}<\max\{\epsilon_{a},\epsilon_{b}\}, if and only if σ2γ2<Hb​Kb+Ka​(2​Hb−Ha)Ha​Hb​(Ka+Kb)/dsuperscript𝜎2superscript𝛾2subscript𝐻𝑏subscript𝐾𝑏subscript𝐾𝑎2subscript𝐻𝑏subscript𝐻𝑎subscript𝐻𝑎subscript𝐻𝑏subscript𝐾𝑎subscript𝐾𝑏𝑑\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\gamma^{2}}<\frac{H_{b}K_{b}+K_{a}(2H_{b}-H_{a})}{H_{a}H_{b}(K_{a}+K_{b})/d}, where ϵa+bsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑎𝑏\epsilon_{a+b} is the generalization error of the model trained by 𝒦a∪𝒦bsubscript𝒦𝑎subscript𝒦𝑏\mathcal{K}_{a}\cup\mathcal{K}_{b}.

Corollary 4.1 implies that client collaboration in FL can benefit individual participants (or coalitions of multiple participants) by enabling them to obtain a model with lower generalization error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon compared to training alone. Nevertheless, collaboration is not always beneficial to all participants, especially when client variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} outweighs data variance γ2superscript𝛾2\gamma^{2} beyond a certain threshold. In such cases, the participation of a client could increase the generalization error of the FL model trained by existing participants. This decline in model performance reduces model utility for existing participants, exhibiting negative network effects of client participation in FL.

To thoroughly investigate the varying network effects of client participation, we quantify it in terms of the change in the generalization error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon of the trained FL model caused by client participation, as defined in Definition 4.2. Then, we derive conditions under which FL network effects are non-negative, established in Theorem 1.

Definition 0 (Network Effects (Easley and Kleinberg, 2012) of Client Participation).

Given any non-empty coalition of existing participants 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K}, the participation of a client n𝑛n results in network effects manifested as the difference between the generalization error of the FL model trained by 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} and the generalization error of the model trained by 𝒦∪{n}𝒦𝑛\mathcal{K}\cup\{n\}, expressed as ϵ​(𝒦)−ϵ​(𝒦∪{n})italic-ϵ𝒦italic-ϵ𝒦𝑛\epsilon(\mathcal{K})-\epsilon(\mathcal{K}\cup\{n\}).

Theorem 1.

Consider any non-empty coalition of existing participants 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K}, the participation of a client n𝑛n with data size D𝐷D will bring non-negative network effects, i.e., ϵ​(𝒦)−ϵ​(𝒦∪{n})≥0italic-ϵ𝒦italic-ϵ𝒦𝑛0\epsilon(\mathcal{K})-\epsilon(\mathcal{K}\cup\{n\})\geq 0, if and only if 1/D1𝐷{1}/{D} is no more than η𝜂\eta in (8), i.e., 1/D≤η1𝐷𝜂{1}/{D}\leq\eta,

(8) η=(2​K+1)​∑i∈ℐKi/DiK2−(K+1)​σ2d​γ2​K,𝜂2𝐾1subscript𝑖ℐsubscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖superscript𝐾2𝐾1superscript𝜎2𝑑superscript𝛾2𝐾\eta=\frac{(2K+1)\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}{K_{i}}/{D_{i}}}{K^{2}}-\frac{(K+1)\sigma^{2}}{d\gamma^{2}K},

where Kisubscript𝐾𝑖K_{i} is the number of type-i𝑖i participants in 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K}, for any i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I}, and K=∑i∈ℐKi𝐾subscript𝑖ℐsubscript𝐾𝑖K=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}K_{i}.

We give the detailed proof of Theorem 1 in the online appendix (Li et al., [n. d.]). With η𝜂\eta in (8), Theorem 1 identifies two factors that determine the network effects of client participation: the data size of the new participant against that of existing participants, and the ratio of client heterogeneity σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} to data heterogeneity γ2superscript𝛾2\gamma^{2}.

  • •

    If the ratio of client heterogeneity to data heterogeneity σ2/γ2superscript𝜎2superscript𝛾2{\sigma^{2}}/{\gamma^{2}} reaches the threshold (2​K+1)​∑i∈ℐKi/DiK​(K+1)/d2𝐾1subscript𝑖ℐsubscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖𝐾𝐾1𝑑\frac{(2K+1)\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}{K_{i}}/{D_{i}}}{K(K+1)/d}, client participation will always increase the generalization error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon of the trained FL model, resulting in negative network effects.

  • •

    Conversely, when σ2/γ2superscript𝜎2superscript𝛾2{\sigma^{2}}/{\gamma^{2}} is less than (2​K+1)​∑i∈ℐKi/DiK​(K+1)/d2𝐾1subscript𝑖ℐsubscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖𝐾𝐾1𝑑\frac{(2K+1)\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}{K_{i}}/{D_{i}}}{K(K+1)/d}, a new participant needs only one-third of the harmonic mean of existing participants’ respective data sizes to positively impact the current model (i.e., reducing generalization error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon), as deduced by the upper bound 3​∑i∈ℐKi​DiK3subscript𝑖ℐsubscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖𝐾\frac{3\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}K_{i}D_{i}}{K} on η𝜂\eta in (8).

However, the composition of participants changes with the participation of new clients, which in turn will affect the specific data size threshold required for future new clients to ensure non-negative network effects from their participation.

Given the above discussions, heterogeneous participants are intertwined to affect the performance of the FL model and the network effects of client participation. To demonstrate how FL model performance and network effects vary with the number of participants from different types, we first take I=2𝐼2I=2 types of clients, each possessing homogeneous data sets (i.e., σ2=0superscript𝜎20\sigma^{2}=0), as an illustrative example, shown in Example 4.3.

Example 0 (Two Types of Clients).

Consider I=2𝐼2I=2 types of clients with σ2=0superscript𝜎20\sigma^{2}=0 in FL, and a coalition of participant 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K}. As the number K1subscript𝐾1K_{1} of type-111 participants in 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} increases, the generalization error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon of the trained global FL model initially increases, but eventually decreases once K1≥⌈(−2​K2​D1−D2+4​K22​(D2−D1)2+D22)/2​D2⌉subscript𝐾12subscript𝐾2subscript𝐷1subscript𝐷24superscriptsubscript𝐾22superscriptsubscript𝐷2subscript𝐷12superscriptsubscript𝐷222subscript𝐷2K_{1}\geq\lceil{({-2K_{2}D_{1}-D_{2}+\sqrt{4K_{2}^{2}(D_{2}-D_{1})^{2}+D_{2}^{2}}})/{2D_{2}}}\rceil. In contrast, the generalization error consistently decreases as the number K2subscript𝐾2K_{2} of type-222 participants in 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} grows.

Example 4.3 provides an interesting insight under the i.i.d. data distribution: when the number of participants with small data size falls below a certain threshold (as referred to type-111 clients in Example 4.3), their participation will incur negative network effects; however, once the number of these participants exceeds the threshold, their participation will yield positive network effects. In contrast, the participation of clients with the largest data size brings positive network effects, regardless of the number of such participants.

After introducing the case of two client types and i.i.d. data distribution, we extend our analysis to general scenarios with I𝐼I client types and non-i.i.d. data distribution, as elaborated in Theorem 2.

Theorem 2.

Consider a coalition of existing participants 𝒦≠∅𝒦\mathcal{K}\neq\emptyset, where Kisubscript𝐾𝑖K_{i} is the number of type-i𝑖i participants in 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K}, for any i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I}, and K=∑i∈ℐKi𝐾subscript𝑖ℐsubscript𝐾𝑖K=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}K_{i}. Then, for clients with type j∈ℐ𝑗ℐj\in\mathcal{I},

  • •

    if 1/Dj<σ2/d​γ21subscript𝐷𝑗superscript𝜎2𝑑superscript𝛾2{1}/{D_{j}}<{\sigma^{2}}/{d\gamma^{2}} and 1/Dj≤η1subscript𝐷𝑗𝜂{1}/{D_{j}}\leq\eta, network effects of client participation are initially non-negative, but eventually become negative as more type-j𝑗j clients participate.

  • •

    if σ2/d​γ2≤1/Dj≤ηsuperscript𝜎2𝑑superscript𝛾21subscript𝐷𝑗𝜂{\sigma^{2}}/{d\gamma^{2}}\leq{1}/{D_{j}}\leq\eta, network effects of client participation are always non-negative.

  • •

    if η<1/Dj≤σ2/d​γ2𝜂1subscript𝐷𝑗superscript𝜎2𝑑superscript𝛾2\eta<{1}/{D_{j}}\leq{\sigma^{2}}/{d\gamma^{2}}, network effects of client participation are always negative.

  • •

    if max⁡{σ2/d​γ2,η}<1/Djsuperscript𝜎2𝑑superscript𝛾2𝜂1subscript𝐷𝑗\max\{{\sigma^{2}}/{d\gamma^{2}},\eta\}<{1}/{D_{j}}, network effects of client participation are initially negative, but eventually become positive as more type-j𝑗j clients participate.

We give the proof of Theorem 2 in online appendix (Li et al., [n. d.]). From Theorem 2, network effects of type-j𝑗j client participation not only depend on heterogeneity ratio σ2/γ2superscript𝜎2superscript𝛾2\sigma^{2}/\gamma^{2} and data size Djsubscript𝐷𝑗D_{j}, but also potentially vary with the number of type-j𝑗j participants, for any j∈ℐ𝑗ℐj\in\mathcal{I}. Specifically, we can divide the network effects of client participation into four regions, as depicted in Figure 3. In Region \nbRoman1, the trained FL model performance (and model utility) first increases and then decreases with the growing number of participants of the same type. In contrast, for Region \nbRoman2, the network effects are always positive, reducing the generalization error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon of the FL model. Region \nbRoman3 and Region \nbRoman4, however, exhibit reverse trends of network effects in Region \nbRoman2 and Region \nbRoman1, respectively. As a result, given any participant coalition 𝒦≠∅𝒦\mathcal{K}\neq\emptyset and heterogeneity ratio σ2/γ2superscript𝜎2superscript𝛾2\sigma^{2}/\gamma^{2}, we can determine the network effects for different client types. For example, when σ2=0superscript𝜎20\sigma^{2}=0 (representing an i.i.d. data distribution, as indicated by line O​A𝑂𝐴OA in Figure 3), the network effects will correspond to Regions \nbRoman3 or \nbRoman4, consistent with our observation in Example 4.3.

So far, through the theoretical analysis of FL model performance, we have investigated network effects arising from the participation of heterogeneous clients. Next, we delve into the social efficiency of the MTS framework, in order to develop a corresponding mechanism that maximizes social welfare.

4.2. Social Efficiency of the MTS Framework

The social welfare (Zeng et al., 2021) characterizes the total payoff for all parties involved. Under the MTS framework, the platform’s payoff is always zero, detailed in Section 3.3.2, and thus, the social welfare is the sum of each client’s payoff. As formulated by WMTSsubscript𝑊MTSW_{\textrm{MTS}} in (7), the social welfare of the MTS framework depends on each client decision snsubscript𝑠𝑛s_{n} and the resultant FL model performance (quantified by generalization error). Through the generalization error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon of the FL model derived in (3), WMTSsubscript𝑊MTSW_{\textrm{MTS}} is a function of the number of heterogeneous participants and model customers, corresponding to different FL social states (Easley and Kleinberg, 2012) introduced in Definition 4.4.

Definition 0 (Social State (Easley and Kleinberg, 2012) of FL).

Consider a group of clients with a set of pure strategies {A,J,B}𝐴𝐽𝐵\{A,J,B\} in (4c). A social state is a vector {𝐊,𝐁}𝐊𝐁\{\boldsymbol{K},\boldsymbol{B}\} gives the number Kisubscript𝐾𝑖K_{i} and Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i} of type-i𝑖i clients with strategy J𝐽J and B𝐵B respectively, for all i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I}.

To determine optimal social welfare and design an appropriate mechanism, we explore the social efficiency of the MTS framework, with an emphasis on socially efficient states in Definition 4.5. We begin by summarizing the features of socially efficient states under the MTS framework in Lemma 1.

Definition 0 (Socially Efficient States).

Socially efficient states {𝐊∗,𝐁∗}={Ki∗,Bi∗,∀i∈ℐ}superscript𝐊superscript𝐁superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑖for-all𝑖ℐ\{\boldsymbol{K}^{*},\boldsymbol{B}^{*}\}=\{K_{i}^{*},B^{*}_{i},\forall i\in\mathcal{I}\} are social states maximizing social welfare, i.e., WMTS​(𝐊∗,𝐁∗)=max⁡WMTS​(𝐊,𝐁)subscript𝑊MTSsuperscript𝐊superscript𝐁subscript𝑊MTS𝐊𝐁W_{\textrm{MTS}}(\boldsymbol{K}^{*},\boldsymbol{B}^{*})=\max W_{\textrm{MTS}}(\boldsymbol{K},\boldsymbol{B}).

Lemma 1.

In socially efficient states under the MTS framework, either no clients obtain the FL model, i.e., ∑i∈ℐ(Ki∗+Bi∗)=0subscript𝑖ℐsubscriptsuperscript𝐾𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑖0\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}(K^{*}_{i}+B^{*}_{i})=0, or all of them obtain it, i.e., ∑i∈ℐ(Ki∗+Bi∗)=Nsubscript𝑖ℐsubscriptsuperscript𝐾𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑖𝑁\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}(K^{*}_{i}+B^{*}_{i})=N.

Lemma 1 implies the only two possibilities for the socially efficient states under the MTS framework. If the optimal social welfare WMTS∗superscriptsubscript𝑊MTSW_{\textrm{MTS}}^{*} is zero, the minimum possible value, then {𝑲∗,𝑩∗}=𝟎superscript𝑲superscript𝑩0\{\boldsymbol{K}^{*},\boldsymbol{B}^{*}\}=\boldsymbol{0} must be a socially efficient state, that is, ∑i∈ℐ(Ki∗+Bi∗)=0subscript𝑖ℐsubscriptsuperscript𝐾𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑖0\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}(K^{*}_{i}+B^{*}_{i})=0. When the optimal social welfare WMTS∗superscriptsubscript𝑊MTSW_{\textrm{MTS}}^{*} under the MTS framework is larger than zero, the socially efficient states will satisfy ∑i∈ℐ(Ki∗+Bi∗)=Nsubscript𝑖ℐsubscriptsuperscript𝐾𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑖𝑁\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}(K^{*}_{i}+B^{*}_{i})=N, indicating that all clients will obtain the trained global FL model, either by participating in training or purchasing it directly.

Building upon the above discussions, we proceed to study the socially efficient states with positive optimal social welfare, which is the transformation of Problem 1 and aligns with its objective function. We formulate such a socially efficient states problem as Problem 2, incorporating the generalization error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon in (3). The socially efficient states addressed in Problem 2 will indicate strategies that mechanism for solving Problem 1 aims to incentivize clients to adopt. This establishes the foundation for us to design the mechanism that optimizes social welfare under the MTS framework later.

When dealing with Problem 2, due to the varying network effects, we divide the type set ℐℐ\mathcal{I} of heterogeneous clients into two distinct subsets: ℐLsubscriptℐ𝐿\mathcal{I}_{L} (low type index) and ℐHsubscriptℐ𝐻\mathcal{I}_{H} (high type index). Such categorization is based on two key factors that affect the network effects of client participation, i.e., client data size Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} and heterogeneity ratio σ2/γ2superscript𝜎2superscript𝛾2\sigma^{2}/\gamma^{2}, as elaborated in Theorem 2. For clients with type i∈ℐL𝑖subscriptℐ𝐿i\in\mathcal{I}_{L}, their data size satisfies that Di≤d​γ2/σ2subscript𝐷𝑖𝑑superscript𝛾2superscript𝜎2D_{i}\leq d\gamma^{2}/\sigma^{2}, whereas the data size of clients with type j∈ℐH𝑗subscriptℐ𝐻j\in\mathcal{I}_{H} is larger than d​γ2/σ2𝑑superscript𝛾2superscript𝜎2d\gamma^{2}/\sigma^{2}. By separately analyzing these two sets of clients, we determine the participation pattern of clients in the socially efficient states that yield positive optimal social welfare WMTS∗>0superscriptsubscript𝑊MTS0W_{\textrm{MTS}}^{*}>0, concluded in Proposition 4.6.

Proposition 0.

Consider any non-empty set of client types ℐ=ℐL∪ℐHℐsubscriptℐ𝐿subscriptℐ𝐻\mathcal{I}=\mathcal{I}_{L}\cup\mathcal{I}_{H}, where Di≤d​γ2/σ2subscript𝐷𝑖𝑑superscript𝛾2superscript𝜎2D_{i}\leq{d\gamma^{2}}/{\sigma^{2}} for each i∈ℐL𝑖subscriptℐ𝐿i\in\mathcal{I}_{L}, and Dj>d​γ2/σ2subscript𝐷𝑗𝑑superscript𝛾2superscript𝜎2D_{j}>{d\gamma^{2}}/{\sigma^{2}} for each j∈ℐH𝑗subscriptℐ𝐻j\in\mathcal{I}_{H}. In socially efficient states with positive optimal social welfare WMTS∗>0superscriptsubscript𝑊MTS0W_{\textrm{MTS}}^{*}>0,

  • •

    if ℐH=∅subscriptℐ𝐻\mathcal{I}_{H}=\emptyset, then Ki∗∈{0,Ni}superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑖0subscript𝑁𝑖K_{i}^{*}\in\{0,N_{i}\}, ∀i∈ℐLfor-all𝑖subscriptℐ𝐿\forall i\in\mathcal{I}_{L}.

  • •

    if ℐH≠∅subscriptℐ𝐻\mathcal{I}_{H}\neq\emptyset, then Ki∗=0superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑖0K_{i}^{*}=0, ∀i∈ℐLfor-all𝑖subscriptℐ𝐿\forall i\in\mathcal{I}_{L}, and Kj∗∈{0,Nj}∪{Kj∈ℕ:∂WMTS​(Kj)/∂Kj=0}superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑗0subscript𝑁𝑗conditional-setsubscript𝐾𝑗ℕsubscript𝑊MTSsubscript𝐾𝑗subscript𝐾𝑗0K_{j}^{*}\in\{0,N_{j}\}\cup\{K_{j}\in\mathbb{N}:{\partial W_{\textrm{MTS}}(K_{j})}/{\partial K_{j}}=0\}, ∀j∈ℐHfor-all𝑗subscriptℐ𝐻\forall j\in\mathcal{I}_{H}.

Proposition 4.6 reveals that socially efficient states typically exhibit an “all-or-none” participation pattern for any client type. However, for clients with type j∈ℐH𝑗subscriptℐ𝐻j\in\mathcal{I}_{H}, partial participation in training can also lead to socially efficient states. The underlying rationale is consistent with Theorem 2. Specifically, according to Figure 3, clients of type i∈ℐL𝑖subscriptℐ𝐿i\in\mathcal{I}_{L} will fall into Region \nbRoman2 and Region \nbRoman4, while clients of type j∈ℐH𝑗subscriptℐ𝐻j\in\mathcal{I}_{H} will occupy Region \nbRoman1 and Region \nbRoman3. Consequently, in socially efficient states, type-i𝑖i clients will either all participate in training to exploit the positive network effects, or all abstain from training to avoid incurring negative network effects. In contrast, clients of type j∈ℐH𝑗subscriptℐ𝐻j\in\mathcal{I}_{H} demonstrate an additional possibility for socially efficient states: only part of the clients participate in training, sufficient to reap positive network effects but not so much as to trigger negative ones (i.e., reaching the threshold of participant number Kj∗={Kj∈ℕ:∂WMTS​(Kj)/∂Kj=0}subscriptsuperscript𝐾𝑗conditional-setsubscript𝐾𝑗ℕsubscript𝑊MTSsubscript𝐾𝑗subscript𝐾𝑗0K^{*}_{j}=\{K_{j}\in\mathbb{N}:{\partial W_{\textrm{MTS}}(K_{j})}/{\partial K_{j}}=0\} that network effects turn from positive to negative).

To summarize, in scenarios with low data distribution heterogeneity (where σ2≤d​γ2/DIsuperscript𝜎2𝑑superscript𝛾2subscript𝐷𝐼\sigma^{2}\leq d\gamma^{2}/D_{I}, implying that ℐH=∅subscriptℐ𝐻\mathcal{I}_{H}=\emptyset), clients of the same type must make consistent participation decisions to maximize the social welfare under the MTS framework, i.e., Ki∗=0superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑖0K_{i}^{*}=0 or Ki∗=Nisubscriptsuperscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝑁𝑖K^{*}_{i}=N_{i}, for any type i∈ℐL𝑖subscriptℐ𝐿i\in\mathcal{I}_{L}. Conversely, with high data distribution heterogeneity (where σ2>d​γ2/DIsuperscript𝜎2𝑑superscript𝛾2subscript𝐷𝐼\sigma^{2}>d\gamma^{2}/D_{I}, implying that ℐH≠∅subscriptℐ𝐻\mathcal{I}_{H}\neq\emptyset), socially efficient states will not involve participants of type i∈ℐL𝑖subscriptℐ𝐿i\in\mathcal{I}_{L}, and only clients of type j∈ℐH𝑗subscriptℐ𝐻j\in\mathcal{I}_{H} potentially participate in FL.

After investigating socially efficient states {𝑲∗,𝑩∗}superscript𝑲superscript𝑩\{\boldsymbol{K}^{*},\boldsymbol{B}^{*}\}, we compare the resultant optimal social welfare WMTS∗subscriptsuperscript𝑊MTSW^{*}_{\textrm{MTS}} under our proposed MTS framework to that of the existing FL framework WFL∗subscriptsuperscript𝑊FLW^{*}_{\textrm{FL}}. Unlike the MTS framework, the existing FL framework (e.g., (McMahan et al., 2017; Tan et al., 2022; Abdulrahman et al., 2021)) only allows clients to obtain and utilize the FL model by participating in the training process, resulting in the social welfare WFLsubscript𝑊FLW_{\textrm{FL}} below:

(9) WFL​(𝑲)=∑i∈ℐKi​(U​(ϵ)−Ci).subscript𝑊FL𝑲subscript𝑖ℐsubscript𝐾𝑖𝑈italic-ϵsubscript𝐶𝑖W_{\textrm{FL}}(\boldsymbol{K})=\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}}K_{i}\left(U(\epsilon)-C_{i}\right).

In contrast, the MTS framework enables clients to access the model through an extra purchasing option, which leads to the social welfare WMTSsubscript𝑊MTSW_{\textrm{MTS}} in (7). As a result, our proposed MTS framework ensures that the optimal social welfare WMTS∗subscriptsuperscript𝑊MTSW^{*}_{\textrm{MTS}} is no less than that of the existing FL framework WFL∗subscriptsuperscript𝑊FLW^{*}_{\textrm{FL}}, as presented in Proposition 4.7.

Proposition 0.

Given any client set 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N}, the optimal social welfare achieved by the MTS framework WMTS∗subscriptsuperscript𝑊MTSW^{*}_{\textrm{MTS}} is no less than that of the existing FL framework WFL∗subscriptsuperscript𝑊FLW^{*}_{\textrm{FL}}, i.e., WMTS∗≥WFL∗subscriptsuperscript𝑊MTSsubscriptsuperscript𝑊FLW^{*}_{\textrm{MTS}}\geq W^{*}_{\textrm{FL}}.

Following the analysis of social efficiency under our proposed MTS framework, we next address its practical implementation. We aim to design a mechanism for the MTS framework that leads self-interested clients, who prioritize optimizing their individual payoffs and thus potentially deviate from socially efficient states, to maximize the social welfare.

4.3. Socially Efficient Mechanism Design

The problem of socially efficient mechanism design under the MTS framework, as formulated in Problem 1, entails the optimization of FL model price p𝑝p and the participation reward risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} for type-i𝑖i clients.

From Lemma 1 and Proposition 4.6, socially efficient states, due to network effects, require clients of each type i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I} to transit between specific social states in a way that maximizes social welfare. For instance, in scenarios with low data distribution heterogeneity σ2≤d​γ2/DIsuperscript𝜎2𝑑superscript𝛾2subscript𝐷𝐼\sigma^{2}\leq d\gamma^{2}/D_{I}, the socially efficient state is Ki∗∈{0,Ni}superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑖0subscript𝑁𝑖K_{i}^{*}\in\{0,N_{i}\}. However, each client n∈𝒩i𝑛subscript𝒩𝑖n\in\mathcal{N}_{i}, irrespective of their type i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I}, will seek to make decision sn∗subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑛s^{*}_{n} that optimizes individual payoff πn∗subscriptsuperscript𝜋𝑛\pi^{*}_{n} in (6c) under the MTS framework, rather than social welfare. Meanwhile, the initial negative network effects, as elaborated in Theorem 2, also prevent self-interested clients from reaching socially efficient states, thereby significantly complicating Problem 1. In response to these challenges, we propose a Socially Efficient Model Trading and Sharing (SEMTS) mechanism, which aligns client payoff with social welfare while accounting for the network effects of client participation, as detailed below.

To maximize the social welfare under the MTS framework, we incentivize heterogeneous clients to overcome the negative network effects phase and exploit positive network effects. Specifically, corresponding to Proposition 4.6, the SEMTS mechanism includes considerations based on distinct data distribution heterogeneity (i.e., different non-i.i.d. levels). For scenarios with low data distribution heterogeneity σ2≤d​γ2/DIsuperscript𝜎2𝑑superscript𝛾2subscript𝐷𝐼\sigma^{2}\leq d\gamma^{2}/D_{I}, we construct a function θ​(𝑲)𝜃𝑲\theta(\boldsymbol{K}) in (4.3) for all clients in the intermediate social states (i.e., 0<Ki<Ni0subscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝑁𝑖0<K_{i}<N_{i}, for any i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I}), defined as follows:

θ​(𝑲)=𝜃𝑲absent\displaystyle\theta(\boldsymbol{K})= ∑i∈ℐ(Ni−KiNi​IU(ϵ(Ki=0))\displaystyle\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}}\left(\right.\frac{N_{i}-K_{i}}{N_{i}I}U(\epsilon(K_{i}=0))
(10) −KiNi​IU(ϵ(Ki=Ni))−Ki​CiN).\displaystyle-\frac{K_{i}}{N_{i}I}U(\epsilon(K_{i}=N_{i}))-\frac{K_{i}C_{i}}{N}\left.\right).

The function θ​(𝑲)𝜃𝑲\theta(\boldsymbol{K}) in (4.3) derives the average payoff of clients in socially efficient states and makes transitions among intermediate social states consistent with individual payoff maximization. In particular, when the participation of clients contributes to achieving socially efficient states, their payoff with the structure in (4.3) will ensure positive network effects (i.e., increase the individual payoff of all participants), and vice versa. In contrast, for scenarios with high data distribution heterogeneity σ2>d​γ2/DIsuperscript𝜎2𝑑superscript𝛾2subscript𝐷𝐼\sigma^{2}>d\gamma^{2}/D_{I}, the SEMTS mechanism focuses on ensuring a non-negative payoff for each participant, in order to initiate positive network effects. We conclude the details of the SEMTS mechanism in the following, which avoids discouraging client participation due to temporary negative network effects or negative payoff.

Mechanism 0 (The SEMTS Mechanism).

Consider any set of client types ℐ=ℐL∪ℐHℐsubscriptℐ𝐿subscriptℐ𝐻\mathcal{I}=\mathcal{I}_{L}\cup\mathcal{I}_{H}, where Di≤d​γ2/σ2subscript𝐷𝑖𝑑superscript𝛾2superscript𝜎2D_{i}\leq{d\gamma^{2}}/{\sigma^{2}} for each i∈ℐL𝑖subscriptℐ𝐿i\in\mathcal{I}_{L}, and Dj>d​γ2/σ2subscript𝐷𝑗𝑑superscript𝛾2superscript𝜎2D_{j}>{d\gamma^{2}}/{\sigma^{2}} for each j∈ℐH𝑗subscriptℐ𝐻j\in\mathcal{I}_{H}. The SEMTS mechanism is as follows:

(1) For the scenario with low data distribution heterogeneity, i.e., σ2≤d​γ2/DIsuperscript𝜎2𝑑superscript𝛾2subscript𝐷𝐼\sigma^{2}\leq d\gamma^{2}/D_{I}, implying that ℐH=∅subscriptℐ𝐻\mathcal{I}_{H}=\emptyset:

  • •

    Model Price p𝑝p:

(11a) p=𝑝absent\displaystyle p= U​(ϵ),𝑈italic-ϵ\displaystyle U(\epsilon), if  ​θ​(𝑲)<0if  𝜃𝑲0\textrm{if }\textrm{ }\theta(\boldsymbol{K})<0,
(11b) p=𝑝absent\displaystyle p= U​(ϵ)−θ​(𝑲),𝑈italic-ϵ𝜃𝑲\displaystyle U(\epsilon)-\theta(\boldsymbol{K}), if  ​θ​(𝑲)≥0if  𝜃𝑲0\textrm{if }\textrm{ }\theta(\boldsymbol{K})\geq 0.
  • •

    Participation Reward risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i}, for any i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I}:

(12a) ri=subscript𝑟𝑖absent\displaystyle r_{i}= Ci−∑j∈ℐKj​CjN,subscript𝐶𝑖subscript𝑗ℐsubscript𝐾𝑗subscript𝐶𝑗𝑁\displaystyle C_{i}-\frac{\sum\nolimits_{j\in\mathcal{I}}K_{j}C_{j}}{N}, if  ​θ​(𝑲)<0,WMTS∗≤0formulae-sequenceif  𝜃𝑲0subscriptsuperscript𝑊MTS0\textrm{if }\textrm{ }\theta(\boldsymbol{K})<0,W^{*}_{\textrm{MTS}}\leq 0,
(12b) ri=subscript𝑟𝑖absent\displaystyle r_{i}= Ci−U​(ϵ),subscript𝐶𝑖𝑈italic-ϵ\displaystyle C_{i}-U(\epsilon), if  ​θ​(𝑲)<0,WMTS∗>0formulae-sequenceif  𝜃𝑲0subscriptsuperscript𝑊MTS0\textrm{if }\textrm{ }\theta(\boldsymbol{K})<0,W^{*}_{\textrm{MTS}}>0,
(12c) ri=subscript𝑟𝑖absent\displaystyle r_{i}= Ci−U​(ϵ)+θ​(𝑲),subscript𝐶𝑖𝑈italic-ϵ𝜃𝑲\displaystyle C_{i}-U(\epsilon)+\theta(\boldsymbol{K}), if  ​θ​(𝑲)≥0if  𝜃𝑲0\textrm{if }\textrm{ }\theta(\boldsymbol{K})\geq 0.

(2) For the scenario with high data distribution heterogeneity, i.e., σ2>d​γ2/DIsuperscript𝜎2𝑑superscript𝛾2subscript𝐷𝐼\sigma^{2}>d\gamma^{2}/D_{I}, implying that ℐH≠∅subscriptℐ𝐻\mathcal{I}_{H}\neq\emptyset:

  • •

    Model Price p𝑝p:

(13a) p=𝑝absent\displaystyle p= U​(ϵ),𝑈italic-ϵ\displaystyle U(\epsilon), if  ​U​(ϵ)<∑j∈ℐKj​CjNif  𝑈italic-ϵsubscript𝑗ℐsubscript𝐾𝑗subscript𝐶𝑗𝑁\textrm{if }\textrm{ }U(\epsilon)<\frac{\sum\nolimits_{j\in\mathcal{I}}K_{j}C_{j}}{N},
(13b) p=𝑝absent\displaystyle p= ∑j∈ℐKj​CjN,subscript𝑗ℐsubscript𝐾𝑗subscript𝐶𝑗𝑁\displaystyle\frac{\sum\nolimits_{j\in\mathcal{I}}K_{j}C_{j}}{N}, if  ​U​(ϵ)≥∑j∈ℐKj​CjNif  𝑈italic-ϵsubscript𝑗ℐsubscript𝐾𝑗subscript𝐶𝑗𝑁\textrm{if }\textrm{ }U(\epsilon)\geq\frac{\sum\nolimits_{j\in\mathcal{I}}K_{j}C_{j}}{N}.
  • •

    Participation Reward risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i}, for any i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I}:

(14a) ri=subscript𝑟𝑖absent\displaystyle r_{i}= Ci−U​(ϵ),subscript𝐶𝑖𝑈italic-ϵ\displaystyle C_{i}-U(\epsilon), if  ​U​(ϵ)<∑j∈ℐKj​CjN,WMTS∗>0formulae-sequenceif  𝑈italic-ϵsubscript𝑗ℐsubscript𝐾𝑗subscript𝐶𝑗𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝑊MTS0\textrm{if }\textrm{ }U(\epsilon)<\frac{\sum\nolimits_{j\in\mathcal{I}}K_{j}C_{j}}{N},W^{*}_{\textrm{MTS}}>0,
(14b) ri=subscript𝑟𝑖absent\displaystyle r_{i}= Ci−∑j∈ℐKj​CjN,subscript𝐶𝑖subscript𝑗ℐsubscript𝐾𝑗subscript𝐶𝑗𝑁\displaystyle C_{i}-\frac{\sum\nolimits_{j\in\mathcal{I}}K_{j}C_{j}}{N}, otherwise.

With the model price p𝑝p and participation reward risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} designed in the SEMTS mechanism, given any social state, the optimal decisions of all self-interested clients align with maximizing social welfare. Each client will make the decision to promote social welfare, i.e., as a participant or model customer that leads to socially efficient states, regardless of any other client’s decision (after considering the coupling with other clients). Furthermore, once clients reach socially efficient states, they benefit from positive network effects without relying on any constructed function, e.g., θ​(𝑲)𝜃𝑲\theta(\boldsymbol{K}). This implies that our mechanism can operate solely on payments from FL model customers rather than requiring extra incentives. We summarize the properties of the SEMTS mechanism in Theorem 3, and give the detailed proof in the online appendix (Li et al., [n. d.]).

Theorem 3.

The SEMTS mechanism leads to the socially efficient states {𝐊∗,𝐁∗}superscript𝐊superscript𝐁\{\boldsymbol{K}^{*},\boldsymbol{B}^{*}\} and achieves optimal social welfare WMTS∗superscriptsubscript𝑊MTSW_{\textrm{MTS}}^{*} under the MTS framework, which operates without incurring extra incentive costs, i.e., ∑i∈ℐBi​p=∑i∈ℐKi​risubscript𝑖ℐsubscript𝐵𝑖𝑝subscript𝑖ℐsubscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}B_{i}p=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}K_{i}r_{i}.

Overall, we have analyzed the network effects of client participation in FL and established an SEMTS mechanism for maximizing social welfare under the MTS framework. Next, we will empirically evaluate our theoretical results through extensive experiments on an FL hardware prototype.

5. Experimental Evaluation

This section begins by introducing the experimental setup. Then, we present empirical results to demonstrate our investigation of FL network effects and evaluate the social efficiency of our proposed SEMTS mechanism and MTS framework.

5.1. Experimental Setup

5.1.1. Hardware Prototype of FL

To better characterize real-world applications, we carry out our experiments on a hardware prototype of FL, as shown in Figure 4. The FL hardware prototype consists of 202020 Raspberry Pis that serve as clients, along with a desktop computer that functions as the central server for coordination (i.e., the platform in Figure 2). The client and server communication occurs through a Wi-Fi router using a TCP-based socket interface.

5.1.2. Heterogeneous Clients and Learning Implementation

We consider a set of N=20𝑁20N=20 heterogeneous clients interested in the FL model. For ease of illustration777While we only present experimental results under this setting due to the page limit, the insights for other function types of model utility and participation cost are similar., we define the FL model utility function of clients as U​(ϵ)=40⋅ϵ−16𝑈italic-ϵ⋅40superscriptitalic-ϵ16U(\epsilon)=40\cdot\epsilon^{-16}, and the participation cost of clients is proportional to their training data size. To simulate the heterogeneity among clients, we categorize 202020 clients into I=3𝐼3I=3 types: 101010 type-111 clients, five types-222 clients, and five type-333 clients. Moreover, we use the widely adopted MNIST (Lecun et al., 1998) and CIFAR-10 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009) data sets in our experiments888We also conduct experiments on the CIFAR-100 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009) and SVHN (Netzer et al., 2011) data sets, which have similar results, as demonstrated in the online appendix (Li et al., [n. d.])., which contain 70,0007000070,000 grayscale images of handwritten digits and 60,0006000060,000 color images of objects, respectively. Table 1 summarizes the training data size Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} of each client type i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I}, as well as the testing data size used to evaluate the trained global FL model performance. While we focus on this small-scale setup, the insights are the same for a larger number of clients and more client types. Below, we will detail the implementation settings on both data sets.

Setup with MNIST Data Set: In the empirical experiments on the MNIST data set, we follow the same setup as in our theoretical analysis, and study extreme scenarios without data distribution heterogeneity, i.e., client variance σ2=0superscript𝜎20\sigma^{2}=0. Specifically, we distribute data samples among 202020 clients in an i.i.d. fashion. Meanwhile, we adopt a convex multinomial logistic regression model, with initialized parameters 𝒘0=𝟎subscript𝒘00\boldsymbol{w}_{0}=\boldsymbol{0} and stochastic gradient descent (SGD) batch size b=32𝑏32b=32. Similar to (Li et al., 2020), we use an initial learning rate η0=0.001subscript𝜂00.001\eta_{0}=0.001 with decay rate η01+rsubscript𝜂01𝑟\frac{\eta_{0}}{1+r}, where r𝑟r is the communication round index, and the local iteration number E=20𝐸20E=20. The total number of communication rounds during the training process is 500500500.

Setup with CIFAR-10 Data Set: In the empirical experiments on the CIFAR-101010 data set, we generalize from our theoretical setting to explore more complex and realistic non-convex models. Meanwhile, we simulate a more practical FL scenario of non-i.i.d. data distribution. In particular, we assign one class of data samples to type-111 clients, five classes to type-222 clients, and all 101010 classes to type-333 clients. We employ a convolutional neural network (CNN) model, which consists of two convolutional layers (Relu activation function), three fully connected layers, and a max pooling layer applied to each convolutional layer. We initialize the CNN model with parameters 𝒘0=𝟎subscript𝒘00\boldsymbol{w}_{0}=\boldsymbol{0} and set the SGD batch size to b=64𝑏64b=64. The initial learning rate is η0=0.1subscript𝜂00.1\eta_{0}=0.1 with the decay rate η01+rsubscript𝜂01𝑟\frac{\eta_{0}}{1+r}, and the local iteration number E=30𝐸30E=30. The total number of communication rounds during the training process is 600600600.

For all experiments on both data sets, we evaluate the aggregated FL model in each communication round, where without loss of generality, we take the test loss as the generalization error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon of the trained FL model. Furthermore, to enhance reliability, our results are averaged over 30 experiments.

5.2. Social Efficiency of the SEMTS Mechanism and MTS Framework

Next, in Figure 5(b) and Figure 6(b), we evaluate the social efficiency of our proposed SEMTS mechanism and MTS framework, respectively.

5.2.1. Social Efficiency of SEMTS Mechanism

In Figure 5(b), we compare the social welfare of our proposed SEMTS mechanism against that of two following benchmarks under the MTS framework:

  • •

    Dynamic Mechanism (Hu et al., 2023): The dynamic mechanism proposed in (Hu et al., 2023) considers clients’ evolving expectations of FL model performance, i.e., a network effects game. However, incomplete information and client heterogeneity could lead this benchmark to deviate from social welfare maximization.

  • •

    Modified FL Mechanism (Yan and Ligeti, 2022): This benchmark is a modified version of the existing socially efficient mechanism in (Yan and Ligeti, 2022), in order to adapt to the MTS framework. Specifically, the modified FL mechanism sets the model price equal to the FL model utility but provides no participation reward, failing to deal with the network effects of client participation.

In the comparison of Figure 5(b), we illustrate how the social welfare of different mechanisms varies with the per-sample participation cost for all clients. From Figure 5(a) and 5(b), as the participation cost increases, the social welfare of all mechanisms declines and eventually reaches zero. However, our proposed SEMTS mechanism achieves significantly higher social welfare than the benchmarks. In particular, benchmarks can only achieve a relatively competitive social welfare to our SEMTS mechanism at low participation costs. Once costs increase further, the benchmarks suffer a quick drop in social welfare due to the client heterogeneity and negative network effects of client participation. In contrast, the SEMTS mechanism can incentivize heterogeneous clients to overcome the temporary phase of negative network effects or negative payoff, maximizing social welfare by exploiting positive network effects. Consequently, our mechanism maintains high social welfare even with high participation costs of clients.

5.2.2. Social Efficiency of MTS Framework

In Figure 6(b), we further present a comparison between the social welfare achieved by our proposed mechanism under the MTS framework versus two benchmarks under the FL framework:

  • •

    Theoretical Optimum of FL Framework: This benchmark implies the highest possible performance of the existing FL frameworks (e.g., (McMahan et al., 2017; Tan et al., 2022; Abdulrahman et al., 2021)) and thus effectively serves as a theoretical upper bound of social welfare for comparison.

  • •

    Dynamic Mechanism (Hu et al., 2023) of FL Framework: Although the dynamic mechanism (Hu et al., 2023) under the FL framework can capture the dynamics of clients’ participation decisions to a certain degree, heterogeneous clients can only obtain and utilize the trained global FL model through participation, failing to maximize social welfare.

As shown in Figure 6(b), with the rise of the per-sample participation cost for clients, the social welfare declines under both frameworks. However, the MTS framework introduces an extra purchasing option and leverages network effects through our designed SEMTS mechanism. This significantly increases the social welfare and makes it more resilient to rising participation costs. As a result, except when the social welfare is zero under both frameworks, the MTS framework achieves an overall social welfare that is 148.86%percent148.86148.86\% and 300%percent300300\% higher than that of the theoretical optimum under the FL framework on the MNIST and CIFAR-101010 data set, respectively.

6. Conclusion

This work provides the first study on social welfare optimization in FL with network effects. Our analysis reveals that the network effects of client participation are not monotonic, which depends on client heterogeneity. To improve social welfare, we propose the MTS framework for FL. By exploiting network effects, our designed SEMTS mechanism under the MTS framework can incentivize heterogeneous clients to maximize social welfare, relying only on payments from model customers without extra incentive costs.

In future works, we will extend our incentive mechanism to consider clients’ strategic decisions of data contribution, such as limited participation using only part of their private data. Additionally, we will refine our theoretical model by exploring clients’ utility and computational heterogeneity. Such advancements, while significantly complicating the equilibrium analysis and mechanism design, are expected to enhance the practicality of our research.
